reviewText: Boring movie, with very wooden actors.Give this one a pass over, it took me 3 separate viewings to get through the whole movie. The acting was so monotone it kept putting me to sleep.It would be nice if they could get some movies on DVD that deserve to be there.TobrukPlay DirtyRed Ball ExpressNone But the BraveJust to name a few.
Title: Back Door To Hell '64

reviewText: "Back Door to Hell" is a 1965 low budget war story about the days leading up to MacArthur's return to the Phillipines. The main notable feature is the appearance of Jack Nicholson pre "Easy Rider" (1969) and one of the few films of pop singer Jimmie Rodgers (not to be confused with the country singer of the same name).This was Nicholson's 10th film, all of them well within the low budget genre and undistinguished. Some were worse than others (e.g., "The Terror") but none suggested the talent they would later be displayed in "Easy Rider" (1969) and, as they say, the rest is history/Director Monte Hellman (1932) was one of several directors who grew up under Roger Corman in the 60s. Hellman did several films in the 60s ("The Terror", "The Shooting", "Ride the Whirlwind") many of them featuring Hellman's good friend and sometimes collaborator Jack Nicholson, himself a protégé of Roger Corman. This particular film was one of two Hellman, Nicholson, and co-star and writer John Hackett did in the Philippines, financed by Robert Lippert who specialized in low-budget double bill films.The top grossing films in 1965 were "The Sound of Music", "Dr. Zhivago", "Thunderball", "Those Magnificent Men...", "That Darn Cat", and "The Great Race". The big Oscar winners were "The Sound of Music" (Film, Director), "Cat Ballou" (Actor Lee Marvin), and "Darling" (Actress Julie Christie). Other notable films that year were "The Collector", "For a Few Dollars More", "The Sons of Katie Elder", "Battle of the Bulge", and "A Patch of Blue"Take it for what it is - a low budget war film.
Title: Back Door To Hell '64

reviewText: This is a gritty WWII adventure set in the Philippines before General MacArthur's return. Standard formula has Jimmy Rodgers and Jack Nicholson sent to take out a Japanese communications center. Dialogue is at a minimum and the story is told almost entirely visually. Jack Nicholson sure looks young and Jimmy Rodgers looks as though he could have made a career as an actor.
Title: Back Door To Hell '64
